Weyerhaeuser Columbus Cellulose Fibers



RMP Executive Summary





Weyerhaeuser Columbus Cellulose Fibers is committed to safely operating its facility to protect its employees, the public and the environment.  EPA requires regulated facilities to submit Risk Management Plans describing the risk management program at its facilities. This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management system at Weyerhaeuser Columbus Cellulose Fibers.  



Accidental release and emergency response policy:



To protect the environment and the health and safety of our employees and the public, we expect full compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. The facility's emphasis on accident prevention is demonstrated by having one of the lowest Recordable Injury Rates in the industry, being among the first pulp & paper facilities in the United States to achieve OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star status and through emphasis on continuous improvement in its safety programs. 



The emergency response program has a trained emergency response team with equipment for responding to on-site fires, hazardous material releases, emergency medical response and rescue. The program has a dedicated emergency response coordinator responsible for coordinating the weekly training and development of the emergency response team. Response activities have been discussed with the Lowndes LEPC and county fire departments and LEPC meetings have been conducted at the facility to increase their awareness of the hazards at the plant as well as the resources. 



The commitment to an injury free work environment is supported by a safety management system that includes

?    Plant Safety & Health Guideline Documentation including Safe Work Practices

?    Regular millwide safety audits

The elements of EPAA?s Risk Management regulations (40 CFR 68) and OSHA Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119) have been integrated into one program to safely manage risks and protect both workers and the community. 



Columbus Cellulose Fibers and Regulated Substances:



The Columbus Cellulose Fibers (CCF) is located in south Lowndes County, Mississippi. The facility manufactures bleached kraft pulp and employs about 350 employees. The bleached kraft pulp operation manufactures papergrade and fluff pulp. The papergrade and fluff pulp is sold and made, respectively, into fine paper and absorbent products such as diapers.



Chlorine dioxide is the only RMP covered chemical used, manufactured or stored on the plant site in quantities above the designated Threshold Quantity. Chlorine dioxide (ClO2) gas is a yellowish/green gas used to bleach kraft pulp. There are 2 ClO2 solution storage tanks with a volume of 94,000 gallons each. The chlorine dioxide generator is capable of manufacturing about 600 gallons/minute at a concentration of about 11.2 grams/liter solution (1.12%). 





Accidental Release Prevention Program:



The CCF accident prevention p

rogram for chlorine dioxide complies with OSHA Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119).



Hazard Assessment, Worst Case Scenario:



The worst-case release scenario for regulated toxic gases involves the ground-level release of the entire contents of the largest vessel at the facility over a ten (10) minute period.  In the worst-case situation, this type of release would coincide with meteorological conditions that would result in minimal dilution of the vessel contents. The endpoint for toxic substances is the maximum airborne concentration below which nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without developing serious health effects which could impair the ability to take protective cover.  The toxic endpoint for Chlorine Dioxide is 0.0028 mg/L (Appendix A of Part 68).  The distance to endpoint was determined using RMP*Comp, a software program developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).



The worst-case scenario for the CCF facility involves a tank rupture, which would result in the release of both of tanks, since the tanks are in communication.  This corresponds to a release of 188,000 gallons of Chlorine Dioxide. With a density of 11.2 grams/liter the 188,000 gallons translates to approximately 17,572 pounds of chlorine dioxide.  The distance to endpoint for this release is approximately twenty five miles (25) miles.



Hazard Assessment, Alternative Release Scenario:



The alternative release scenario is an event more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and will reach an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists. In determining the distance to endpoint for the alternative release scenario, any mitigation controls employed in the process can be used.  The distance to endpoint for the alternative release scenario was determined using RMP*Comp.

Procedures: 



CCF process engineers, operators, and management work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safely performed. Employees participate in operating procedure development in several ways:

1.    Employees are consulted during procedure development and implementation to determine if the procedures accurately reflect what is practiced in the field and what additional measures should be added to increase worker safety and protect the environment.

2.    Development of Standard Operating Procedure (SOPs) are assigned to employees that have recognized knowledge, experience, and job skills related to the assigned procedure. 

3.    Implementation of new processes or procedures is assigned to a commissioning team. These assignments typically include an opportunity for a critique of the work processes and procedures.





Employee Training: 



CCF trains employees to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. Employees are trained through self-taught learning materials including operation manuals, educational modules and computer based education programs. In addition, employees are trained one-on-one through on-the-job training in the field. Employees are encouraged to identify education needs and take part in education development and implementation. Skills are demonstrated through written exams, oral exams, and through proficiency demonstrations. The requirements of 40 CFR Part 68 allows the responsible official of the facility to certify that any employee involved in the process has been trained regarding process operations.  This certification can be found in Appendix B, Form 4. 



Refresher training is required as well as the initial training.  Refresher training will be provided at least every three years, but can be more often, as needed.  It is imperative that operators are trained and knowledgeable about the current operating procedures of the process.



Mechanical Integrity

: 



CCF maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. Employees record equipment history, data and observations, maintain the SAP maintenance system database, and generate Reliability Maintenance System reports. The employee doing the actual test and inspection work is typically asked to review and comment about manufacturer's recommendations for preventive maintenance procedures and test frequencies. Employees take part in equipment failure reviews, participate in work process critiques, and are encouraged to make recommendations for change.  Inspections and testing procedures shall follow good engineering practices, and the frequency shall follow manufacturers' recommendations or more frequently, if necessary.  If any deficiencies are found they will be corrected before further use of the equipment or in a timely and safe manner.



Management of Change: 



The CCF management of change program evaluates and approves all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, and procedures for a covered process to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. Process changes that are determined to be "a replacement in kind" are approved without completing the full management of change process. Changes other than "like kind" must be approved through the management of change process to ensure that potential accidents resulting from the change are prevented, safety concerns of the changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, there is a technical basis for the change, time period for the change is adequate, proper authorizations are obtained, and affected employees are notified of the changes and have been properly trained for the change.



Pre-startup Review: 



CCF performs a safety review of a new or modified process before the process is placed into service to ensure that the process has been prepared to op

erate safely. This review ensures that drawings have been updated, training is complete, procedures are written, and the necessary documentation is made before the modification is put into service. Team members with appropriate knowledge and skills are employed in the pre-start up review process at the CCF facility. Team members are encouraged to ask safety questions, participate in pre-start up safety reviews, and discuss any concerns identified.



Compliance Audits: 



In addition to regular safety and environmental compliance audits, CCF conducts Process Safety Management (PSM)/RMP compliance audits against the provisions of OSHA's PSM and EPA's RMP requirements. In these audits, adherence to both Corporate and mill policies, internal procedures and standards are verified. Team members are interviewed as part of audit protocols to permit them to give input on the specific issues being audited. Audit reports, response plans and status updates are shared with affected employees. 



The minimum requirements for the compliance audit include performing an audit at least once every three (3) years; maintaining the last two (2) audit reports at a minimum; conducting audits by at least one (1) person knowledgeable in the process; documenting the appropriate response to each finding; and documenting any deficiencies found and corrective actions taken. 



Incident Investigation: 



CCF facility investigates all incidents that could have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents/incidents can be prevented. Team members are involved in incident investigation since their knowledge and skills in operation and maintenance are necessary to conduct the investigation. Once investigation team reports become available, the results and recommendations of the team are made available to those working in the process or operation. Communication is in the form of a report, which is circulated among employees and is discussed i

n scheduled safety meetings and in ad hoc meetings with team members. 



A report of the incident will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation which includes at a minimum the following:



1.     Date of incident;

2.     Date investigation began;

3.     Description of the incident;

4.     Factors contributing to the incident; and

5.     Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.



Employee Participation: 



CCF facility has developed a written employee participation program for covered processes to help ensure that the safety concerns of the CCF workers are addressed. Team members participate in compiling process safety and maintenance information with field checks to verify the accuracy of P&IDs, loop drawings, and equipment drawings used in normal work  processes and through communication of observations made during the normal conduct of their work-particularly those that reflect operational safety hazards.



Hot Work Permits (Safe Work Practices): 



CCF establishes a hot work permit program to control activities which may result in fires or explosions in covered processes. Team members, with appropriate job skills and experience, participate in the review of safe work practice procedures through their involvement with safety sub-teams, site-central safety core team, or ad-hoc task teams. A cross section of knowledgeable team members may be called upon to draft procedures and revisions to procedure. During the development or changes to critical activity procedures, emphasis is placed on involving a core functional team that will be affected by the procedure.  A permit issued shall document that the fire prevention and protection requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252 have been implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.  It shall indicate the dates authorized for hot work and identify the object on which the hot work is to be performed.  The permit shall be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.



Contractors: 



CCF facility

has established a program to ensure that contractor activities are performed in a safe manner. Team members at CCF have an integral role in the interface with contractors working at the site. They often work side-by-side with contract employees and have a high level of knowledge about how the contractor's work can affect or be affected by the process or adjacent processes. Each site team member and contract employee is encouraged to ask questions and to raise concerns about unsafe work activities or conditions. Site team members are expected to inform contract employers of the potential hazards of fire, explosion or toxic releases when repairing equipment so that contractors can work on it safely. Contractors are given a PSM Safety Orientation to the hazards of the process, how to protect themselves from those hazards and what to do in the event they do get exposed. After the Safety Orientation they must pass a written exam to document their understanding of the material presented. 



Emergency Planning and Response: 



CCF facility has established a written emergency response program to help safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances. A formal review process to solicit and obtain employees input on millwide procedures exists to improve site emergency response plans. Employees and participants in both safety incidents and drills conduct critiques to get comments and observations, identify learnings, identify opportunities for performance improvement and improve both emergency response planning and responder performance. Communication to both team members and contractors takes place on both formal and informal levels so that there is a complete understanding of the actions one should take in an emergency situation. The written plan, which is consistent with the approach in the National Response Team's Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance ("One Plan"), contains the following elements:



1.    Procedures for informing the surrounding public and loca

l emergency response agencies in the event of an accidental release from the facility;

2.    Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment of accidental human exposure;

3.    Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release;

4.    Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment; 

5.    Procedures to review and update the plan as necessary; and 

6.    Training for all employees in relevant procedures.



Trade Secrets: 



It is stated in the preceding sections of the Employee Participation Plan (14.0) that team members have access to information developed to meet the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management Rule. It is the intent of the site management to disclose to team members and contract employees as necessary (subject to 29 CFR 1910.1200(i) trade secret protection constraints where applicable) the process safety related information needed to have an informed workforce whose efforts and attention to detail will ensure the CCF continues to be a safe workplace. 



While some information is appropriately claimed as confidential information the following may not be claimed as confidential:

1.     Certain registration data required by 68.160,

2.    Offsite consequences analysis required by certain part of 68.165,

3.    Accident history required by 68.168,

4.    Prevention program data required by certain parts of 65.170, and

5.    Prevention program data required by certain parts of 65.175.



5 Year Accident History:



In the past 5 years, there has not been any injury as a result of chlorine dioxide exposure.



Emergency Response Program:



An Emergency Response Team capable of providing multiple emergency response functions is available on the plant site. The team has regular Haz-Mat, fire fighting, and confined space, high angle recue training and drills. In addition, the team is trained in CPR, patient packaging and handling and blood borne pathogens.



In emergencies, the production coordinator is the incident commander who d

etermines the degree of hazard and risk posed to public health and the environment. An internal alert millwide alarm system can be sounded to summon the emergency response team. Regulatory, emergency management agency, and public notification procedures are documented in the Quality System. Mutual aid requests are made through 911 notification. 



Continuous Improvement:

Continuous improvement in our safety and environmental programs is the expectation at CCF facility. Near miss and safety incident investigations, root cause analysis, and corrective action implementation support continuous improvement. Team members have been trained in conducting risk assessments to further evaluate the jobsite and work procedure risks. Individual safety plans are being developed for each employee on the plant site defining their role and commitment to safe work practices. These improvements are to support continuous improvements in safe work practices.
